title: Dialogue Techniques Quiz
description: Explore how skilled writers craft dialogue to reveal character, advance plot, and create tension

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of dialogue in fiction?
options: To reveal character, advance the plot, and provide information
To make the book longer
To fill space on the page
To replace all narration

questions.question: What is a 'dialogue tag'?
options: A label put on a character
A phrase that identifies who is speaking, such as 'she said' or 'he asked'
A price tag on a book of dialogues
A type of quotation mark

questions.question: What is 'subtext' in dialogue?
options: A whispered conversation
The text written below the main text
The underlying meaning or unspoken feelings beneath what characters actually say
Subtitles in a foreign film

questions.question: Why might a writer use dialect or slang in dialogue?
options: To show off their vocabulary
To make characters feel authentic and reflect their background and culture
Because proper English is boring
To make the text harder to read

questions.question: What is an 'action beat' in dialogue writing?
options: The rhythm of spoken words
A brief description of a character's action used instead of a dialogue tag to attribute speech
A fight scene
A dramatic pause in speech

questions.question: What does 'show, don't tell' mean in the context of dialogue?
options: Use illustrations instead of words
Always use visual descriptions
Let characters reveal their emotions through what they say and how they say it, rather than the narrator stating their feelings
Only use dialogue, never narration

questions.question: What is 'exposition through dialogue'?
options: Conveying important background information naturally through characters' conversations
Characters visiting an exposition or fair
A character reading from a textbook
The opening monologue of a play

questions.question: Why is the dialogue tag 'said' often recommended over more elaborate tags like 'exclaimed' or 'proclaimed'?
options: Because publishers pay per word
Because 'said' becomes invisible to the reader and does not distract from the dialogue itself
Because 'exclaimed' is not a real word
Because 'said' is the shortest word

questions.question: What is 'stichomythia'?
options: A long monologue
A rapid exchange of short lines of dialogue, often used to build tension or conflict
A form of written correspondence
A type of ancient Greek pottery

questions.question: In Ernest Hemingway's writing, dialogue is known for being:
options: Written entirely in dialect
Always humorous
Extremely elaborate and wordy
Sparse, understated, and relying heavily on subtext

questions.question: What is 'internal dialogue' or 'inner monologue'?
options: A conversation that takes place in a dream
Dialogue between two characters inside a building
Dialogue written in italics
A character's thoughts presented as words in their mind

questions.question: What writing problem is called 'on-the-nose dialogue'?
options: Dialogue where characters state exactly what they feel without any subtlety or subtext
Dialogue spoken while touching one's nose
Dialogue about noses
Dialogue that is perfectly written

questions.question: Why do writers sometimes use interruptions or incomplete sentences in dialogue?
options: Because the writer forgot what they wanted to say
To save ink
Because grammar rules do not apply to dialogue
To create realism, show emotion, or build tension

questions.question: What is a 'Socratic dialogue'?
options: A monologue by Socrates
A dialogue about ancient Greek food
A debate between two politicians
A form of conversation that uses questions and answers to stimulate critical thinking and explore ideas

questions.question: In screenwriting, what is 'V.O.' written next to a character's name?
options: Volume Off
Vocal Order
Very Original
Voice Over, meaning the character speaks but is not seen on screen
